prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to work through this. The user is asking if the author (the wife) is in the wrong in this situation. Let me read through the scenario again.

The husband set up his home office in their bedroom because he prefers the view. The wife suggested the basement for less disruption. Since he's working from the bedroom a few days a week, she has to keep the kids from disturbing him, which limits her access to their floor. She has to take care of the house and kids while working from home too. She told him she can't guarantee silence if he's in the bedroom, and he's upset she isn't quiet during his calls. She's saying he's the asshole for not taking the basement, while he thinks she's the asshole for not being quiet.

First, the husband is choosing a space that's not ideal for minimizing disruption despite the wife's suggestions. The basement was an option that would allow him to work undisturbed and give the wife more space. By choosing the bedroom, he's creating a situation where the wife has less room to manage her responsibilities. The wife is then trying to balance both her work and household duties while also accommodating his preferences. 

The key points here are about mutual consideration. The husband could have prioritized the wife's needs by using the basement, but he didn't. The wife is not in the wrong for not being able to guarantee silence when he's in a space that's not conducive to quiet. She's already shouldering a lot, and his choice is making her tasks harder. 

So, the husband's decision to work in the bedroom, despite the wife's input, leads to her being unable to perform her duties without interference. The wife isn't in the wrong for not keeping him undisturbed because he didn't choose the more practical location. Therefore, the answer should be B (No, the author is not in the wrong).
